     Mr R Ravindran (Marine Parade):  Sir, I beg to move,

 

     That the total sum to be allocated for Head N of the Estimates be reduced by $100.

 

Regional Outlook

 

      Sir, the Asian region is full of optimism and great hope due to the economic growth being back on track and the regional giants China and India showing good economic growth.

 

     China and India.  With the rise of China and India in the region, both will flex their muscles and be respected as emerging global powers.  China, with its growing economic and military capabilities, will be a big factor in regional calculations.  One view is that China will seek to avoid conflict in the region and focus on economic growth and internal stability.  The other view is that a strong China will seek to adjust regional power arrangements to its advantage, risk conflict with neighbours and some external powers in the region.

 

     On the other hand, India will seek to expand its economic and military might too and seek greater engagement with ASEAN and the region.  China and India will seek, in their own way, a greater involvement in regional matters and will want to be acknowledged as emerging powers.  Both countries are keen to secure economic and natural resources in the world, and rivalry with each other and other powers to secure these natural resources will pose a challenge in the region.

 

     The question arises then:  how does Singapore, as a country and as part of

Column:1500

ASEAN, go about engaging the two countries in a manner that fits their growing power and desire to be recognised as global powers, if not regional powers?  How will it fit in with our overall policy of keeping all big powers engaged in a region to ensure our economic prosperity and a peaceful region?

 

     North East Asia.  Sir, the triangular relationship between the US, China and Japan will underpin the security and geo-strategic framework in North East Asia.  But with relations between Japan and China not being at their best, Japan proposing to amend its constitution to give them the mandate for the self defence forces to be deployed overseas, North Korea blowing hot and cold over its nuclear policy, and the Taiwan issue surfacing intermittently, North East Asia will certainly remain an area for potential big power confrontation.  I would like to ask the Minister for his assessment of the state of affairs in North East Asia.

 

     Next, on ASEAN.  While I am glad to see the group moving ahead with good steam, I would like the Minister to give an update on the state of ASEAN, the progress of the ARF and new initiatives to engage the various regional and global powers in the dialogue.

 

     I am happy that Singapore is engaging as part of ASEAN the different regions through APEC, ASEM and, very recently, through the Asia

Column:1501

Middle East Dialogue (AMED) and the proposed East Asia Summit (EAS).  I would like to ask the Minister for an update on these dialogues and the new initiatives we can expect to bring the regional blocs together.  I would like to ask the Minister on what is Singapore's position on the participating countries to be invited for the East Asia Summit.

 

     Next, on Middle East.  I am glad that Singapore has taken a keen interest in the Middle East and the Arab world, with SM Goh Chok Tong playing a leading role in opening up a new frontier in our relations there.  I certainly look forward to Singapore strengthening our relations with many Middle Eastern countries who share similar visions and look forward to closer links.  I would like to ask the Minister for an update on the new initiatives we will be embarking to develop closer relations with the Middle Eastern countries.

 

     Sir, we are playing a pivotal role in ensuring that South East Asia continues to be a place of peace and prosperity.  Our leaders are working very hard to ensure that Singapore's interest is respected, our views are given careful consideration in many capitals, and our geo-political strategic outlook taken into account when policies are drawn up.  We are respected as an independent and sovereign country.  We are, most importantly, seen as being just and fair in our dealings on international matters and in international organisations.  This is due to good leadership in the past and present, and also having a team of good diplomats who understand and defend Singapore's vital interest at all times.  I would like to take this opportunity to compliment the Ministry of Foreign Affairs and our diplomats for keeping the Singapore flag and our reputation flying high in the international arena at all times.

 

      

Strategic Review of Key Countries

 

     Ms Irene Ng Phek Hoong (Tampines):  Sir, Singapore's relations with Malaysia and Indonesia are very important with implications on the mood and development not only of the three countries but also of the South East Asian region.  As a region, we are living in challenging times.  On the security front, terrorism and piracy still pose a danger.  On the economic front, the region is facing increasingly intense competition from low-cost countries such as China and India.  Those

Column:1502

countries hit by the tsunami disaster, especially Indonesia, face the costly prospect of reconstruction. And politically, some countries, including Malaysia, Indonesia and Singapore, have just undergone political transition.  But I would argue that we are in a better position today than we have been for a long time to forge a closer partnership with each other to build a stronger region.  First, all three countries  -  Malaysia, Singapore, Indonesia  - have new leaders who are forward looking and who have emphasised their resolve to strengthen relations further.  Second, all three leaders have been able to demonstrate through their actions that the specific disagreements between their individual countries and Singapore should not be allowed to define the broader relationship and over-shadow the many areas that we cooperate with each other.

 

     But some old thorny issues remain, and they can set back the good progress made if we are not careful.  With Malaysia, the old issues are a legacy from the Mahathir era, and I am glad that Senior Minister Goh Chok Tong and Malaysian Prime Minister Abdullah Badawi have met recently to discuss the steps to take the talks forward.  But I note that now even Johore wants to have a public say in the negotiations, as Johore Mentri Besar Abdul Ghani Othman was quoted as saying, "The state wants to be heard on three key areas  -  reallowing Singapore military aircraft into Malaysian airspace, the water price review and the proposed bridge."  Sir, I am not sure that this state-centric approach will help the two countries to resolve the outstanding issues with the larger regional cooperation in mind.  Indeed, much of the focus of the Malaysian media and Johore politicians seem to centre around the issue of the bridge.  Previously, it was a crooked bridge, but now the Malaysian proposal is for a straight one.  While I do not see why the Causeway should be demolished for this, I would like to ask the Minister if

Column:1503

there is any merit at all to this idea of a straight bridge, and if it can bring any benefit to Singapore as well, and the cost, taking into account the long-term view and the larger picture of regional cooperation.  Sir, we will stand firm on fundamentals but we must be broad-minded enough to accommodate Malaysia's interests where our own national interests are not diminished.

 

     As for Indonesia, the issue of the extradition treaty, among other issues, is also an old one, but we seem to have moved forward on this.  According to newspaper reports, PM Lee Hsien Loong was quoted as saying that Singapore would sign a treaty with Indonesia following his meeting with the Indonesian President.  Sir, Indonesia has, for nearly a decade, sought an extradition treaty with Singapore, but we have been reluctant to do so.  Certainly, concluding an extradition treaty will allow both sides to focus on more important and pressing issues.  Can I ask the Minister why Singapore has decided to go ahead to work on this treaty now at this time after years of expressing reluctance to do so?

 

     I would also like to ask the Minister's update on our relations with China, US and India which have also been evolving.

 

 

      

ASEAN

 

      Mr Tan Soo Khoon (East Coast): Sir, the reputation of ASEAN as a credible and effective regional body is a challenge that has confronted the organisation for many years and has been discussed in this House quite often.  ASEAN meetings are unfortunately viewed, whether rightly or wrongly, often by outsiders as talk shops where officials hand out statements, speeches, declarations, joint communiques and memorandums of understanding, and little of substance is achieved.  One has difficulty, in fact, keeping track of the scores of documents that are churned out at ASEAN Summits.

 

Column:1504

     At ASEAN meetings, the underlying principle is that ASEAN must resolve problems and face challenges in the spirit of solidarity, cooperation and consensus building.  These are nice words and the language that flows out at such meetings is inevitably couched in diplomatic language that sometimes tells you little.

 

     A case in point is the issue of terrorism.  It is a regional security issue that threatens all ASEAN countries.  Yet, information and action from countries where the source of terrorism originates is difficult and slow to come by.  Another case in point, hampered by the policy of non-interference in other member's affairs, Thailand's problems with Muslim insurgents in its south cannot be discussed at ASEAN level, although it is an issue that threatens to blow up and affect our member states.

 

12.15 pm

 

     At each annual ASEAN summit, there is grandiose talk

of creating a common market and implementing a Free Trade Area. So many deadlines have been announced in the past - in fact, so many ideas and deadlines have been announced that I myself am confused whether, at times, ASEAN is talking about a FTA or a common market, or do they mean the same thing - the latest I hear is the creation of an ASEAN Economic, Social and Security Communities by 2020, but I thought that ASEAN first talked about a free trade area in 1976, and now after 29 years we are told we have to wait a further 15 years to attain some kind of economic community.  So you can understand my confusion.  Perhaps the next 15 years will allow time for ASEAN to set even later deadlines.

 

    Another case in point that underlines ASEAN's credibility is Myanmar's membership. Even with the continual arrest of Aung San Suu Kyi by the military regime, ASEAN continues to pretend that

Column:1505

all is well and praises the efforts of the regime to bring about a transition to democracy. Here we have a person whose party won elections in 1990, and for 15 years has been under house arrest; so you have to really take it with a pinch of salt when the leaders of ASEAN make statements saying that what is happening in  Myanmar is actually making progress towards democracy and political reform.

 

     Now, the credibility stakes for ASEAN will be raised further next year because that is when Myanmar takes over the chairmanship of the organisation. Other countries have called Myanmar all sorts of names, some are so crude that I would not even mention them in the House.  But already a number of ASEAN dialogue partners have said that they will not attend ASEAN meetings next year, including the ASEAN Regional Forum in Yangon next year.

 

     So where does that leave ASEAN in the eyes of the world?  Can ASEAN afford to be led by a member state which has little respect from the rest of the free world?

 

     I believe that Singapore as one of the founding members of ASEAN - and certainly one of its more respected ones - can do much more to shake up the organisation and restore its credibility.  We have to work with like-minded members to jolt Myanmar into action.   

 

     In the 1990s, ASEAN applied pressure on Cambodia and pushed the leaders towards reform by accommodating the opposition before it allowed Cambodia to join ASEAN.  Likewise, we can do the same with Myanmar.

 

     Without these concrete steps, I am afraid ASEAN will continue to be viewed as a paper mill churning out  piles and piles of documents that attract little attention not only from outsiders, but

Column:1506

even from its own people.  It is time for ASEAN to take concrete steps so that its legitimacy can be further enhanced.  

     The Senior Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Education and Minister for Manpower (Mr Hawazi Daipi): Sir, I share Members' - Mr Ravindran and Mr Tan Soo Khoon - concern over the future growth and influence of ASEAN.  An enlarged ASEAN is already facing a problem of integration economically and politically because of the differing developments of the member countries.  Now, ASEAN, collectively, has also to contend with new poles of influence and development, namely, China, and possibly in future India too.

 

     How would ASEAN strengthen relations among its members, bearing in mind all these two major challenges?  And how would ASEAN members collectively strengthen its role vis-a-vis China and India in future?  Would including China and India in its regional initiative speed up the decline of its importance in the region, including in East Asia?

 

      

ASEAN + 3

 

     Mr Chay Wai Chuen (Tanjong Pagar):  Mr Chairman, Sir, I share some of the views expressed just now by Mr Tan Soo Khoon on ASEAN's regional bloc issues.  My concern here is, with the prospect of this new framework that has been discussed or raised - ASEAN + 3, including dialogues with China, Japan and Korea - how does the Ministry look at this new enlarged framework in the context of further and future development of ASEAN? 

 

     Obviously, the initial discussion on ASEAN + 3 has been on currencies, capital flows and investments in the region.  But something could perhaps be developed out of this to enable ASEAN to move towards a new level.  We have seen the development of EU and over the last decade, the tremendous development.  Of

Column:1507

course, there are problems always with integration but, at least, attempts are made truly and honestly forward in integrating economies, bringing down tariffs, and allowing free flow of factors of production, and so on. 

 

     My view is, with all these talks and dialogues which have been going on in ASEAN for years, leading not necessarily to very visible goal-posts, should we spearhead or really review what could be done?  What is the Ministry's thinking towards this future development, and whether in the development of things in the world, if we continue to talk and not walk the talk, would ASEAN run the risk of being irrelevant?

      

ASEAN and Myanmar

 

     Mr Ravindran:  Sir, the removal of the Prime Minister of Myanmar, General Khin Nyunt, and a number of his closest associates in October and November last year, is seen as a setback for the process of national reconciliation within the country.  There is no timeline for the roadmap to implement the promised changes and the proposed National Convention appears not to include the key partners to ensure a lasting solution.

The SPDC seems to be going nowhere and has failed to keep its commitment to its own population and to the international community. 

 

     Many members of ASEAN have expressed disillusionment over the developments in Myanmar.  If I may quote the Foreign Minister of Malaysia, Mr Syed Hamid Albar - he was quoted as saying in 2004:

 

     "If Myanmar does not address the problem, then not only Myanmar is going to be affected but the credibility and integrity of ASEAN as a whole is going to be affected."

 

     In 2003, the Foreign Minister of Indonesia, Mr Hassan Wirajuda, stated:

 

Column:1508

     "Burma is a dilemma for ASEAN, which must be tackled now."

 

     Sir, Myanmar, if nothing changes, will become the Chairman of ASEAN in 2006.  It will mean hosting of the summit of ASEAN leaders there.  As it is, Myanmar has been a thorn in ASEAN's relations with the EU and the US.  ASEAN's reputation has been tarnished by Myanmar's continued membership.

 

     Sir, I am a member of the ASEAN Inter-Parliamentary Caucus for Democracy on Myanmar which is seeking to bring about democratic change in Myanmar.  My colleague, Mr Charles Chong, is also on the caucus.   So I would like to ask the Minister for his view on Myanmar becoming the Chairman of ASEAN in 2006 and whether there is any proposal being considered to bypass Myanmar as Chairman.  If not, how is ASEAN preparing itself to handle the international fallout by allowing Myanmar to become the Chairman of ASEAN in 2006?

      

Relations with Malaysia, Indonesia and Thailand

 

     Mr Leong Horn Kee (Bishan-Toa Payoh):  Mr Chairman, Sir, it is important for any country to maintain close and cordial relations with its neighbours, but without compromising on its sovereign rights and interests.  Therefore, I would like to discuss our relations with our three closest neighbours, namely, Malaysia, Indonesia and Thailand.

 

     Senior Minister, Mr Goh Chok Tong has recently met with Malaysia's Prime Minister Abdullah Badawi.  We read from the newspaper reports that they had a very good and fruitful meeting.  However, no details were released on the progress of their discussions on bilateral issues.  In particular, I believe Singaporeans are interested to know whether we have made progress on the water agreement discussions.  Singaporeans are relieved to

Column:1509

hear from our leaders that we have sufficient water and would not need to renew the 2011 Water Agreement with Malaysia; and by 2061, Singapore would have developed more water resources.  The other issue of public interest is Malaysia's proposal to build the so-called "crooked bridge" to replace the present bridge, and now it is going to be a straight bridge but still a new bridge.  All Singaporeans feel that the existing causeway is serving us perfectly, so why the need to spend about $1 billion to build either a crooked or a straight bridge?

 

     On Indonesia, the Indonesian President, Susilo Bambang Yudhoyono visited Singapore recently.  He was thankful for the fast response and great help given by Singapore during the recent tsunami disaster.  He has called our Prime Minister "his good friend".  President Yudhoyono signed an Investment Guarantee Agreement (IGA) with Singapore and has urged Singapore businessmen to invest in Indonesia.  Both sides agreed to work on an extradition treaty.  I share Ms Irene Ng's queries on the purpose of this treaty.

 

     Sir, Indonesia is a close neighbour with a population of 238 million people.  It represents a huge market which Singapore can do business with.  Therefore, it is encouraging to read about the positive attitude of the current Indonesian President towards Singapore.  This is a sharp contrast to his predecessors, one of whom called Singapore "the Little Red Dot".

 

     As for Thailand, Prime Minister Thaksin Shinawatra has performed well in his country's recent general elections. However, he is facing some difficulties in dealing with the Muslim fundamentalists in South Thailand.  Thailand is another potential business partner with a huge population of 65 million people.  Premier Thaksin is now one of the most senior

Column:1510

leaders in ASEAN.  Whether he would succeed in solving the problems in southern Thailand as well as our relations with our neighbours, like Malaysia and Indonesia, will have a bearing on the geopolitics and progress of ASEAN as an economic and political bloc. 

 

     Mr Chairman, Sir, we know that politics by its nature is always in a state of flux.  I would like to hear from the Foreign Affairs Minister what he sees as the near and medium term developments that will affect Singapore's relations and interests vis-a-vis our three closest neighbours, namely, Malaysia, Indonesia and Thailand.

      

Singapore-Indonesia-Malaysia Relations

 

     Mr Ravindran:  Sir, our relations with our two closest neighbours are of great significance to us.  The feeling among regional observers is that ties are now warm and will only get better.  With new leaders at the helm of the three countries, there is a sense that there is good personal chemistry between our Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong, Prime Minister Badawi and President Bambang Yudhoyono.

 

     We have shown that we are true friends of Indonesia in the overwhelming manner the Government and the people responded to the tsunami victims in Aceh.  I was very impressed by the very large Singapore turnout for the business dialogue and the lecture delivered by President Bambang recently.  It shows that the business community shares the optimism in the relations between the two countries.

 

      The new Indonesian government is focusing on economic growth to generate jobs and ensure stability for the country.  I am happy to note that we have concluded the Investment Guarantee Agreement with Indonesia and that we are in discussion with the Indonesian government on some of the bilateral issues, such

Column:1511

as the extradition treaty and on delineating the borderlines between the two countries.  I would like to ask the Minister to give us an update on the state of relations between the two countries and whether there has been any progress on other outstanding bilateral issues.  In particular, I would like to ask the Minister how Singapore is working with Indonesia in helping in the economic priority areas outlined by the new Indonesian government.

 

     Sir, our relations with the Badawi government look warm and there is a sense of optimism that many of the bilateral issues with Malaysia will be resolved.  The many commercial deals between the companies in the two countries signal that there is good support for this process from the relevant quarters.  The numerous visits by Ministers and civil servants from both ends augur well for even better relations.  I would like to ask the Minister for an update on the state of relations on the bilateral talks on unresolved issues and his assessment on new areas of cooperation between the two countries.

ASEAN

 

     ASEAN is a "paper machine", as Mr Tan pointed out.  Sometimes, it is understandable that we should be impatient with its elliptical processes, that we seem to spend a lot of time talking, backtracking and then moving forward again, not always moving in a straight upward course.  But if we take a step back and look at ASEAN in its historical development, it has been very good for all of Southeast Asia.  When President Soekarno was leading Indonesia, ASEAN was not possible because he had a certain view of the Nusantara in the region.  Under President Soeharto, Indonesia promoted regionalism, and so ASEAN was born.  ASEAN was only possible because Indonesia, the largest country, showed restraint, accommodating countries big and small.  So, Brunei when it became independent, immediately was asked to join ASEAN. 

 

Column:1521

     During the Cold War, when Vietnamese divisions crossed the Mekong and threatened us, ASEAN was galvanised to action at the UN and other international forums and helped maintain the peace which enabled us to develop economically for many years.  Then, when the Indo-China war ended, to our initial surprise, one of the first things that Vietnam did was to ask to apply to join ASEAN.   And even though it is by no means a perfect organisation, relations within the region have been kept soft.  We do not have armies massing along borders. 

 

     If you compare ASEAN as a regional grouping with similar groupings in South America or other parts of the world, we are probably the most successful grouping among developing countries.  And when we are suddenly seized by big issues like SARS or the tsunami, the instinct to coalesce is now deep in us.

Column:1522

whether ASEAN would remain viable, the meetings that we had programmed for kept us going together, and maintained a certain steady course of action.

     Mr Tan Soo Khoon asked what is the difference between the Free Trade Area and the Economic Community.  The Free Trade Area expresses a common desire to bring tariffs down.  Tariffs are coming down all over the world anyway.  But the Economic Community takes us a step further into the areas which go beyond tariffs, to services, to the harmonisation of standards and increasingly, to the settlement of disputes in an institutional way.  And although this was not noticed by many people, at Bali, the leaders made an important decision:  for the first time, trade disputes would be referred to independent dispute settlement panels instead of being resolved by Ministers, because with Ministers, problems tend to be blurred and ambiguous decisions made.  Little by little now, because disputes will go to these panels, the way agreements are drafted legally will become very important, and in the coming years, an ASEAN jurisprudence of resolving trade disputes will grow.

Column:1530

     The reason why we are concerned is that what happens in Myanmar affects ASEAN as a whole and our relationship with our Dialogue Partners.  Last year, ASEAN countries took a firm position with the EU that Myanmar could not be excluded from the Asia-Europe Meeting in Hanoi.  We stood our ground and we succeeded.  But subsequent developments in Yangon undermined our position.  I hope that the ASEAN spirit of consultation and consensus will enable us to find a solution for next year.  Unless the Myanmar authorities handle the situation carefully, ASEAN's credibility and cohesion would be jeopardised.  The Foreign Ministers will be meeting in retreat next month in Cebu, Philippines, and I expect that they will be discussing this subject behind closed doors.

Global governance

 

     As a small country, we have a strong interest in promoting good global governance based on clear rules and the equality of nations.  The proper functioning of international organisations like the UN and the WTO is very important to us.   For this reason, we support the reform of the UN and the early conclusion of the Doha Development Agenda.   Now that UNESCO is much better run, we have decided to rejoin it, first as an observer and later, in two or three years' time, as a full member.  I am happy to report that the World Intellectual Property Organisation (WIPO) has recently decided to establish a regional facility in Singapore.

 

Seizing opportunities

    We have seen the waves of IT innovation from the years of development in phases over the years and, recently, the focus has been on the adoption and use of IT applications and the infrastructure to support them.  Instead of installing them on their own, the option of outsourcing IT infrastructure is becoming more common using the "utility" model to buy IT services.  Indeed, corporations have become increasingly vigilant and attentive to ensuring that there is a business case for IT investment and track the performance to ensure that the purported benefits are realised.

 

     The consumers in Singapore, however, have been more carefree in their spending on mobile phones and portable devices. We have now a phenomenal penetration rate of 97% on mobile phones in Singapore. We recently saw the highly successful nation-wide 3G network roll-out which I believe surpassed the expectation of the three mobile operators.

Column:1596

     Our literary artists, whether writing in English, Chinese, Malay or Tamil, need people to buy their books.  That is the real support they need.  In a globalised world, this is a difficult challenge.  Chinese writers compete in the market with writers from China and Taiwan, Malay writers with those from Malaysia and Indonesia.  Tamil writers from those in Tamil Nadu.  And those who write in the English language, they have to compete with everybody, with writers from the whole world, because famous authors who write their works in a non-English language would have their works translated into English.  Writers now serve a global market, and the same book, the Da Vinci Code, is the best seller in Singapore and many countries around the world, including non-English speaking countries.

 

     Singapore literary artists must write for the regional and global audience.  Some Singapore writers have succeeded in doing this.  Eugene and Yen Puay Noi in the Chinese language, Abdul Ghani and Masuri in the Malay language,  J M Sali in the Tamil language, are well-known overseas.  Tan Tee Hwee's second novel, Memo Inc, was internationally acclaimed and was on the W H Smith's top 20 Best Sellers list in Asia for more than two months. 

 

     MICA has schemes to help and encourage Singapore literary talent.  The idea is to give them an opportunity to get a start, so that Singaporeans with the talent of Dan Brown, the author of the Da Vinci Code, would have an opportunity to emerge and take their place on the regional and global literary scene.  MICA

Column:1597

supports the local literary arts scene through programmes managed by the National Arts Council (NAC).  The NAC provides financial assistance to writers through publishing grants, training and travel grants, as well as project grants for literary arts events and projects.  In FY 2004, financial assistance to writers through these grants increased by 16%.  So in reply to Dr Ong's request for aid to writers, I am happy to let him know that last year, $325,000 was given to literary artists to support their work.  In addition, we are also helping them with housing.  The NAC supports the literary arts, through the Arts Housing Scheme, which subsidises arts premises to literary arts groups, such as the Sin Sheng Poet Society and the Association of Singapore Tamil Writers.

     Sir, Mr Loh Meng See was concerned about the health of the infocomm sector and asked if Singapore's IT sector could grow when there was near stagnation in global IT spending.  I am happy to say that our IT sector is healthy.  Singapore's infocomm industry remains one of the key engines of growth for the economy.  The pipeline for investments remains strong.  Last year, the infocomm and media cluster was the second strongest contributor to investment commitments in the service industry, with $647 million in business spending, generating $1.3 billion in total value-add and 3,000 professional and skilled jobs.  Revenues from the infocomm sector are expected to grow by

Column:1598

6% in 2004 to $34.7 billion and to grow by 7.4% this year to $37.3 billion.  The number of infocomm professionals employed is expected to grow by 3% to more than 108,000 in the coming year. 

 

     There are new growth opportunities in the infocomm sector, as pointed out by Mr Loh.  Business process outsourcing (BPO) is a growth area and we have enjoyed success in this area.  As pointed out by Mr Loh, Singapore is ranked No. 1 in the world for offshore projects per million population and ranked 6th globally in absolute numbers.  Our high quality telecoms infrastructure, conducive regulatory environment, and well-educated workforce make us a very competitive location for higher-end outsourcing processes and services.  These include business continuity, disaster recovery, IT strategy and security implementation. 

 

    The use of infocomm technologies is pervasive in Singapore.  Singapore's Internet penetration rate is one of the highest in the world, with two out of every three households and three out of every four companies, having access to the Internet.  More than 42% of households have a broadband connection. 

 

     Mr Zainudin has pointed out that the technologies IT and media sectors are converging and asked what MICA is doing about that.  The next few years will be exciting ones, with opportunities for the innovative as the telecoms, broadcast and media and IT sectors converged.  Convergence could very well shake up all the sectors.  But the shake-up will provide opportunities for those who are innovative.  For the consumers, convergence holds exciting promises.  Some time in this exciting future, on a mobile one could talk to another person in New York at a fraction of the cost today because the voice information would be digitalised and sent across the Internet using VOIP technology.  Or, one could watch the news or a movie on one's handphone or

Column:1599

plug one's handphone on a plasma screen to watch a movie - a service that could be provided by one's telecoms operator.  Or one could have wireless broadband through WIMAX, a service provided by one's broadcaster.  

 

    The infocomm, media, and broadcast sectors are overlapping and merging.  To promote growth in this new merged sector, MICA and its statutory boards, the IDA and the MDA have adopted a multi-pronged strategy.  IDA has been actively facilitating the deployment of infrastructure that will enable Singapore to employ these new technologies.

 

     Sir, young people today could look forward to an exciting world that technology is creating for them.  Sir, some Members may remember the excitement we enjoyed during our National Service days playing "Space Invaders" at the canteen in SAFTI.  Young people today have not heard of "Space Invaders".  They play computer games on Playstation 2 in near virtual reality with movie screen quality images.  Members in this House communicate with email.  The young talk to the world on blog sites.  We think in terms of SDU to meet new people.  They link up to the Third Degree on Friendster.  It is a really cool world for young people. 

 

     While these technological advances are exciting, we must protect the vulnerable young from being exploited and prevent technology from being used for illegal purposes.   To address these challenges, MDA already has in place a light touch class licence regulatory framework that ensures the industry maintains some minimum standards with regard to the Internet, SMS, MMS, and other forms of new media services.  We also have deterrent legislation like the Computer Misuse Act and the Penal Code to prevent the illegal use or abuse of such technologies.  MICA also intends to introduce a legislation to control spam this year.  But there is a limit to what

Column:1600

legislation could do in an environment where information travels across borders in bits and bytes.  We need to educate parents and children to become more discerning and responsible end-users.  We also need to educate organisations to pay more attention to security and the use of the same default passwords on the SDU website was a contributing factor to the lapse in security at that site.  So MDA is working with companies and volunteer groups like Parents Advisory Group for the Internet (PAGi) and Touch Community Services.  To help the community deal with Internet security, MDA has provided over $2.3 million in funding support for activities and programmes that help the community deal with dangers on the Internet.

 

      Sir, the infocomm and media sectors offer great opportunities for our economy and new exciting lifestyles for our young.  With the light regulatory touch, MICA's goal is to maximise these opportunities and minimise the downside.  I have presented an overview.  In our digital age, for more information, Members could log on to www.mica.gov.sg.  I thank the Members for their cuts.

     And should cultural imperatives be left entirely to the market?  In practice, the quota system works for the music industry.  Canada, South Africa, France

Column:1603

 Captioning of TV News

 

     Sir, I was very happy when the Prime Minister, at his swearing-in, held up a caring and inclusive society as part of his vision for Singapore.  Hence, I would like to raise an old issue, which under the new dispensation should be looked at more kindly. 

 

     The hearing-impaired community would love to feel included, and part of Singapore.  One crucial way to do this is via TV captioning or subtitling of the news and other programmes.  Many people think mistakenly that the issue is about access to information.

We have newspapers, Teletext, the Internet, as they say.  But reading the newspapers, like surfing the Net, is a solitary activity.  Watching TV, however, can be a shared and favourite pastime, especially among families.  Just imagine if you were to go home tonight and find your family

Column:1604

enjoying a TV show.    What if you cannot share in that moment because you cannot hear and you cannot understand what is happening?

     TV captioning is about equal participation in society.  It is about integrating the hearing impaired into our society.  It has been said that not having captioning or subtitling is like a blind person not being able to read Braille.

 

     So, for a start, I would like  to ask whether MDA can ensure that the daily local news on all channels have either subtitles or captions.  Please consider that we are an ageing population.  Almost 400,000 or 11% of our population are 60 years and above.  The elderly are the fastest growing category of individuals who are deaf and hard of hearing.

 

     Captioning would also help the overall development and education of our hearing-impaired children. There are about 5,300 people registered with the Singapore Association for the Deaf.  The total number of hearing impaired here probably is higher.  This is similar to New Zealand, which has a smaller population base and 7,700 hearing-impaired people.  Yet, it captions at least 65 hours of programming a week.  Australia has a Bill that requires above seven hours of captioned programmes daily, including the news and current affairs shows.  In 2010, all programmes are to be captioned.

 

     What do we have, save for one-off occasions like the National Day Rally?  It is one thing to say we consider the needs of our hearing-impaired.  It is another to provide for it.

 

     While costs may be a concern, there are more options now than before.  Newsrooms are becoming electric.  Scripts can be entered into a computer network and broadcast as captions.  If

Column:1605

needed, breaking news can be excluded, given the greater difficulties.  Advertisers can come on board to generate goodwill.  MDA collects $95 million in annual radio and TV licences to pay for public service broadcasting and support national and community interests.  We could use this.  Maybe each channel could select one show each week to caption too.

 

     The point is, let us have something, anything, on a long-term basis.  We are limited only by our creativity and political will.  I would be most happy to work with MDA to enact a Bill on this, if necessary.

     On subtitling or captioning for the hearing-impaired raised by Ms Olsen, I would say that it is difficult for pro

     Sir, I note the many comments and queries on the operational readiness of the SAF.  This has been raised by Mr Ravindran, Dr Ong Chit Chung, Dr Warren Lee, Mr Hawazi and Mr Leong Horn Kee.  I would like to assure Members that the operational readiness of the SAF is a key priority.  Singapore's geo-strategic situation makes us more vulnerable than most countries.  Our small size means that we have no manoeuvring space and no strategic depth to fall back on.  We cannot afford to sit back and absorb an attack.  Besides having a good early warning system, it is imperative that our defence force must maintain high operational readiness.

Column:1648

that the operating expenditure reflected in the Budget book reflects the total expenditure on the SAF which includes, what you normally call, "operating expenditure", but it also includes things like training, pay and emoluments for SAF servicemen and reservists, as well as capital expenditure on the SAF. So it is not just all operating expenditure.

 

     Prof. Ivan Png asked how MINDEF would change its expenditure should the budget be raised or cut by 5%.  MINDEF takes a very careful and considered approach in drawing up the defence budget and we would not spend more money just because money is available.  Similarly, we would not cut spending hastily so that the capabilities and operational readiness of the SAF are compromised.  MINDEF's budget is drawn up based on what is needed to enable the SAF to carry out its core mission of defending our nation in the current situation and, also, in the years to come.  MINDEF's budget is put through a rigorous process and scrutiny every year.  Priorities are established by the joint staff in conjunction with the services in a process where the different planning agencies test their plans and ideas against each other.  So, there is always a contest of ideas, and this 5% up or 5% down question is continually being asked, not just on the total defence budget but parts of the defence budget. The budget plans and priorities are again scrutinised by MINDEF staff before they are approved each year.  But beyond assessing the question of what MINDEF would do with the budget at the margin - 5% more or 5% less - at least once every five years, MINDEF carries out a thorough review and reassessment of our long-term force structure needs.  So it is more than a 5% either way kind of assessment, but a fundamental rethink of what we would need for our defence in the future.
